I got the idea from folks like Joel Hooks and others who are challenging the notion of a traditional blog.

The concept of a digital garden is that itâ€™s a place where your ideas grow. Itâ€™s easy to intake endless amounts of random information. Itâ€™s harder to actually learn something concrete and then articulate that learned thing. Itâ€™s harder still to connect what youâ€™ve learned to a broader repertoire of skill and knowledge.

Anyone can grow a million dandelions in a grassy lot; it takes intentionality to cultivate a garden.

And at the same time, no garden is perfect. Weeds grow incessantly. Any order is ultimately fleeting. And sometimes, you endure the sparse appearance of a particularly small bush, trusting that in time gaps will fill and the whole space will eventually be green and lush. The wise gardener embraces all these aspects as part of the gardening process.

So with this digital garden: the goal isnâ€™t perfection. Itâ€™s thoughtful cultivation of knowledge toward true cognitive growth.
